citation:Producer.producer:Name: Preconception and Pregnancy in Inflammatory Bowel Disease Clinical Research Program

citation:Description.dsDescription:Text:
The study objective is to assess the effectiveness of a  web-based information portal to improve the knowledge and attitudes of patients with IBD with respect to maternal health and chronic disease. This study will help to develop educational tools for improving knowledge regarding pregnancy and IBD. Pre- and post- intervention reproductive knowledge was compared using the CCPKnow (Crohn's and Colitis Pregnancy Knowle
dge) survey. Patient factors (age, reproductive history, IBD history, medications, education, marital status, clinic/specialist access) and preferences for knowledge translation method were measured and assessed. If a patient was randomized to the interactive group, the effectiveness of videos, slides, sets, PDFs, and mini quizzes were compared. Usage was also tracked, including time spent on modules and components of modules,  number of times accessed.

ore:describes.socialscience:Frequency: Data collected at baseline, 2 months, and 8 months.
ore:describes.Title: Improving Knowledge Regarding Pregnancy and Inflammatory Bowel Disease
ore:describes.socialscience:Sampling Procedure: The target sample size was 100 study participants; the actual sample size was 80 study participants.
ore:describes.socialscience:Universe: Adults (both females and males) who have IBD and their partners.
ore:describes.citation:Related Material:
Huang VW, Chang H-J, Kroeker KI, et al. Does the level of reproductive knowledge specific to inflammatory bowel disease predict childlessness among women with inflammatory bowel disease? Canadian Journal of Gastroenterology
& Hepatology. 2015;29(2):95-103.
ore:describes.Alternative Title: Improving Knowledge Regarding Pregnancy and IBD
ore:describes.Data Sources: CCPKnow (Crohn's and Colitis Pregnancy Knowledge) survey
ore:describes.socialscience:Characteristics of Data Co: Approximately 20 people of the 100 who registered did the baseline survey but did not do the second survey after 2 months.
ore:describes.socialscience:Actions to Minimize Losses: Reminder emails about the second survey (2 month) were sent out.
ore:describes.Subject: Medicine, Health and Life Sciences
ore:describes.schema:name: Improving Knowledge Regarding Pregnancy and Inflammatory Bowel Disease
ore:describes.dvcore:conditions: Access to deidentified data may be permitted to the general public. The data producer determines access on a case-by-case basis. Contact the data producer directly to discuss terms and conditions of access. A basic data sharing agreement form is required (ie. Agree to not attempt to re-identify the records so as to relate the information on the file to a particular person).
ore:describes.schema:includedInDataCatalog: Women and Children's Health Research Institute (WCHRI)
